Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Understanding Complexity in Markovian Interaction Networks: Self-Organization, Functional Stability, Robustness, and Evolutionary Behavior

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many natural and man-made systems of interest to scientists and engineers are composed of groups of individual elements interacting with each other, through specific channels, to produce and regulate appropriate responses. Examples include chemical reaction networks, cellular (signaling, transcriptional, and metabolic) networks, pharmacokinetic networks, epidemiological networks, ecological networks, social networks, neural networks, multi-agent networks, etc. Understanding the fundamental properties and design principles of such networks is an exciting and challenging research problem whose solution requires development of new theoretical and computational approaches. To complicate matters, the dynamics of most interaction networks are inherently nonlinear and stochastic. A unifying approach is thus needed to concurrently encompass the deterministic and stochastic aspects of networks that can lead to common approaches and methods for the modeling and analysis of a diverse body of interaction networks.

The main goal of this research is to develop a general theoretical and computational approach for characterizing and analyzing complexity in nonlinear interaction networks with Markovian dynamics. While complexity may be difficult to characterize directly, this research rigorously pursues and quantifies the prevalent hallmarks of complexity: self-organization, functional stability, robustness, and evolutionary behavior. The investigators study a potential energy landscape perspective that relates topographic features of the landscape to these fundamental network properties. To achieve feasibility and computational efficiency of the main goals of this effort, new tools are being developed for computing the time evolution of the probability distribution of the underlying stochastic population dynamics. Rigorous mathematical, algorithmic, and computational approaches are then proposed for modeling the emergent behavior and complexity of Markovian interaction networks as well as for studying their functional stability and thermodynamic robustness by probabilistic sensitivity analysis techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many natural and man-made systems of interest to scientists and engineers are composed of groups of individual elements interacting with each other through specific channels to produce and regulate appropriate responses. Examples include biochemical reactions in cells that keep humans alive and well, networks of people interacting within a social environment, networks of healthy people coming in contact with individuals infected by some disease, as well as networks of interacting neurons inside the human brain. Understanding the fundamental properties and design principles of such networks helps biomedical engineers to develop better treatments for human diseases, social engineers to figure out how ideas are formed from social interactions, public health scientists to understand how contagious diseases spread in a population, and neuroscientists to discover the secrets of how human consciousness arises from the complex interactions of neurons in the human brain.

The dynamic behavior of most interaction networks is inherently nonlinear and random. This makes their modeling and analysis a challenging problem. As a matter of fact, nonlinear networks with random dynamics can be subject to important complex behavior that cannot be modeled and analyzed by traditional techniques. For example, a network of biochemical reactions in human cells can abruptly switch behavior leading to the onset of a serious disease, such as cancer.

In this project, we focused our effort on developing a mathematical and computational methodology that concurrently encompasses the nonlinear and random aspects of networks and can lead to common mathematical approaches and computational methods for the modeling and analysis of a diverse body of interaction networks. We did so, by borrowing fundamental concepts from physics and thermodynamics, such as the concept of a potential energy landscape, and developed formal statistical signal processing and information-theoretic techniques for the modeling and analysis of complex interacting networks with nonlinear and random dynamics.  Our approach relates quantifiable topographic features of well-defined energy landscapes to fundamental measures of network complexity, such as self-organization, functional stability, robustness, and evolutionary behavior. Our effort achieved a number of important outcomes:

  • New theoretical and computational approaches for modeling emergent behavior in complex interaction networks as well as for studying their robustness and functional stability.
  • A statistical methodology for testing the validity of analytical and computational approximations to complex interaction networks.
  • A statistical approach for constructing real-life complex biochemical reaction networks from available data in a particular biological context with applications to understanding the molecular biology of autism and the formation of glioblastoma in the human brain.
  • An information-theoretic approach for quantifying epigenetic information landscapes and their uncertainty in human cells, as well as computational methodologies for analyzing this information in order to help biomedical researchers understand how epigenetic modifications lead to human disease.
  • A realistic reaction-diffusion complex network for modeling de novo synthesis of hydrogels in living cells in order to better understand the physiological role that gels formed in living cells by protein aggregates play in normal cellular function as well as in disease initiation and progression.
  • A curriculum unit for K-12 math and science teachers, published in teachengineering.org, in which students can learn about complex reaction networks and their applications in a variety of different scientific disciplines and real-world applications.
